description: One of the largest botanical gardens in the former Soviet Union, the Batumi Botanical Garden is a spectacular 108-hectare (270-acre) paradise of subtropical flora located on the Black Sea coast at Mtsvane Kontskhi (The Green Cape). Founded by Russian botanist Andrey Krasnov in 1912, this living museum houses over 2,000 species of woody plants from around the world, organized into nine phytogeographic sections representing different global regions.
highlights: Nine floristic sectors representing Caucasian humid subtropics, East Asia, New Zealand, South America, the Himalayas, Mexico, Australia, and the Mediterranean
Collection of 2,037 taxonomic units of woody plants, including 104 species of Caucasian origin
Extensive collections of rhododendrons, camellias (78 varieties), and magnolias
Spectacular groves of bamboo, eucalyptus, and palm trees
17 Red List protected species including the endangered Podocarpus nubigenus
Unique living bridge formed from a 72-year-old double-breasted liriodendron that fell during a 1985 storm
Founder Andrey Krasnov's grave and statue located within the garden
Up to 170 rose species on display
Research facilities including herbarium collections, experimental plots, and living seed banks
Stunning Black Sea coastal views throughout the garden
tips: Allow 3-4 hours for a comprehensive visit, though nature enthusiasts may want half a day
Visit between June-October for the best blooms and favorable weather
Spring is spectacular for blossoms, autumn for fall colors
Take the electric bus tour (10 GEL for foreign travelers) to cover more ground, especially useful for the large 108-hectare area
Bring water bottles - there are spring water fountains throughout the garden where you can refill
Pack snacks or a picnic as food options inside are limited to a couple of snack stands
Arrive early in the day during summer months to avoid the midday heat
Wear comfortable walking shoes as there's extensive walking on varied terrain
Located 9-10 km north of Batumi - take minibus 31 or bus 10, or taxi for 15-20 lari
General admission is 20 GEL for foreign visitors
Don't miss the North American section with the unique living bridge
Visit the camellia collection - some varieties were planted before the garden's official founding
Camping is available for 50 GEL per night in designated areas
vibe: A tranquil scientific sanctuary where global botanical wonders meet dramatic Black Sea coastline. This is both a serious research institution and a spectacular natural retreat, offering a peaceful escape into diverse plant worlds from Mediterranean groves to Himalayan flora. The garden radiates a sense of living history, with century-old specimens, the founder's grave, and Soviet-era scientific legacy creating an atmosphere of botanical reverence. Perfect for nature lovers, photographers, families, and anyone seeking a serene day surrounded by extraordinary plant diversity and stunning coastal views.

additional_information.location: Mtsvane Kontskhi (The Green Cape), 9 km north of Batumi
historical_notes: Started by Andrey Krasnov in the 1880s, officially opened 1912
Krasnov worked with French gardener D'Alphonse and Georgian Yason Gordeziani
Expanded significantly under Soviet Union from 1925
Became principal institution for study of Caucasian maritime subtropical cultures
Some camellia varieties predate the garden's official founding
additional_information.conservation_status: Major center for study and conservation of subtropical flora, operates living seed banks for biodiversity preservation
